Award.AwardTitle: Travel Funding for Workshop at RIMS Kyoto
Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years there is a very intensive research activity in areas of Mathematics related to the so called Grothendieck's anabelian program, where some of the outstanding open problems are the section conjecture and its implications in arithmetic geometry, the description of the Galois structure of number fields via the arithmetic action on (geometric) fundamental groups, and the profinite Teichmueller theory and its relation to Arithmetic and Number Theory. Naturally, one of the major effort in this area of mathematics is to understand the bigger picture of Grothendieck's anabelian program in the context of Algebra and Number Theory. The half year long NAG Programme at the Isaac Newton Institute in Cambridge, UK, in July-December 2009, was dedicated to this circle of questions and turned out to be a very successful activity.

Through the present conference funding Proposal, the PI facilitates the participation of American scientists (grad students and junior/senior researchers) to a two part mathematical research activity in Kyoto, Japan, during October 20-30, 2010, which could be viewed as a continuation of the NAG Programme. The wide majority of the participants to the Kyoto activity come from Europe and Japan. The first part of the activity is of introductory nature and will host several talks and special activities for graduate students and young researchers, thus enhancing training and technological understanding, whereas the second part of the activity will do both: First, present of wide picture of the state of the art of Grothendieck's anabelian program through a series of survey talks by world leading experts in respective related areas of research. Second, give junior and senior scientists the opportunity to present their newest findings and ideas in this area of research. Thus the activity will contribute to creating a broad basis for international cooperation, training, and scientific exchange at all levels. The outcomes of the activity will be disseminated to the mathematical community via the Internet and a proceedings volume to be published by the Mathematical Society of Japan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scope of this award was to provide financial help to scientists and graduate students from American universities to participate to a research and training activity centered around the Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences (RIMS) Kyoto, Japan, during Oct 20-30, 2010. The activity was a direct continuation of the 2009 half year long NAG Programme held at the Isaac Newton Institute Cambridge, UK (organizers: J. Coates of Cambridge Univ, UK, M. Kim of the University College London, P. Schneider of University of M\"unster, Germany, M. Saidi of Exeter Univ, UK, and the PI). The first part of the Kyoto activity, a Gasshuku-gata Seminar, was organized by H. Nakamura (chair; Nakayama Univ), Leila~Schneps (Universite Paris 7),  A. Tamagawa (RIMS Kyoto), Y.Hoshi (RIMS Kyoto), and the PI, and took place at the IIAS Kyoto (http://www.iias.or.jp) during October 20-23, 2010. This
part of the activity had a strong mentoring/learning component via introductory talks and discussion sessions, and offered as well extensive time for research/discussions in smaller groups. The second part
of the activity was the conference Development of Galois--Teichmuller theory and anabelian Geometry, organized by Nakamura, Schneps, Tamagawa, and the PI. It took place at RIMS Kyoto during Oct 25-30, 2010, being at the same time The 3rd MSJ SI Meeting (http://mathsoc.jp/meeting/msjsi10). Among the many participants, the activity gathered together the world leaders in areas of mathematics under discussion (most of them being active at Institutions in Europe and Japan).

There were six survey talks --accessible to a general mathematical audience, in particular completely accessible to advanced grad students-- and many of the talks were at least in part accessible to advanced graduate students, junior researchers, and non-expert mathematicians. The participants from American Institutions funded by the award included four professors, two assistant professors, three post docs, three graduate students (one other graduate student had to cancel his participation due to sudden sickness). Except the graduate students, all the above participants gave talks in either the Gasshuku-gata Seminar at the IIAS, or in The 3rd MSJ SI Meeting at the RIMS. The proceedings of The 3rd MSJ SI Meeting, that is of the conference at the RIMS Kyoto, will be published in the prestigious Mathematics Society of Japan Conference Proceedings Series (with the co-organizers of the conference as the editors of the volume). It will have about two dozens contributions, with a total of more than 650 pages. Among the contributions, there will be five contributions by participants funded by this award.

Finally, because the senior participants used partially other funding resources, a few funds of the award were saved and could be applied towards supporting three graduate students to participate to two followup learning and training activities during the summer of 2011. The first one was a summer school on valuation theory held at the Mathematical Village in Izmir, Turkey (http://matematikkoyu.org/en/etkinlik) during June 22-27; the second one was a research and training activity at the Hausdorff Institute for Mathematics (HIM) Bonn, Germany, during June--August 2011. The unique working and learning atmosphere at HIM proved to be very productive, and the weekly seminar organized by the senior researchers in residence was a good opportunity for lengthy discussions (which involved several other graduate students and junior researchers visiting HIM). All three graduate students gave talks during both activities and had an intensive and active exchange of ideas with the senior and other junior researchers participating in the two activities.
